Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: The main protest march is beginning in a few minutes, and you are needed at the front to lead the first chant.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I’m about to step up to the front of the protest march. The crowd is gathering, banners raised, and everyone’s eyes are on me—I’m supposed to lead the first chant, set the tone, and keep the energy high. But the text is from my mom: “Just checking in. Hope you’re okay. Love you.” I haven’t replied to her last message from two days ago, and I know she worries when I go silent, especially with all the news about protests lately. I can almost hear her voice, gentle but anxious, asking if I’m eating well, if I’m safe. The organizers are waving me over, and the megaphone is thrust into my hand. My heart pounds—not just from the adrenaline of the march, but from the guilt of not being the attentive son she hopes for. I want to text her back, reassure her, but the crowd is chanting my name, waiting for me to lead. I stand there, torn, my thumb hovering over my phone, caught between the expectations of my family and the cause I believe in.
